articleinfo.releaseinfo: This manual describes version &appversion; of Synaptic Package Manager.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The &app; enables you to manage your software. software is organizied in so called packages and &app; features upgrading, installing, removing or even of such software packages.
Modifcations on the status of packages are not immediatly . &app; collects the planned modifications in a queue commits them to apt. Apt is an unified package manager backend RPM and DEB systems.

sect2.title: Toolbar
sect2.para: The toolbar provides quick access to global actions and a quick search for packages.

sect2.title: Package List
sect2.para: The package list shows all known packages by default. You can apply filters to narrow down the list of shown packages, see .

textobject.phrase: Shows the package list in the &app; main window.

sect2.para: To arrange the packages you can choose the follwing modes from View menu:

row.entry: Groups the packages by their initial name letter.
Groups the packages by their section, e.g. "admin", "base", "gnome", etc.
Groups the packages by their status, e.g. "installed", "not installed", "obsolete" etc.
Groups the packages by their tag. Tags are keywords provided by third parity. Only Debian GNU/Linux with installed "debtag" supports this feature.

sect2.para: The column order and the used colors can be changed in the preferences, see .

sect3.title: Quick Search
sect3.para: To find a package name in the list of shown packages follow these steps:

listitem.para:
Type the name or a part of it into the
located in the toolbar. &app; will automatically jump to the first matching package in the list.
To find the next matching package press the the forward button next to the find field.
To begin the search again from the beginning of the package list click on the upward button.

sect3.title: Advanced Search
sect3.para: The advanced search is a special filter for the package list. Only matching packages will be shown in the package list.

listitem.para: Open the search dialog Package Search... from the menu.
Type the search expression into the find field, e.g. "mp3 ogg player".
Select the fields that you want to search in, e.g. "name" and "description"
Click on Find to start the search. In our example only music players and related packages will be listed.

tip.para: You can create more sophisticated filters with the .

sect2.title: Installing Packages
sect2.para: To install one or more packages follow these steps:

listitem.para: Query the package repositories for the latest version of the package(s):
Choose Actions Update from the menu.
Click on Update in the toolbar.

Select the package(s) that you wish to install in the
.
Queue the selected packages for installation:
Click on Install Latest Package in the package control area.
Choose Package Install Latest Version from the menu.
Right click on the package and choose Install Latest Version from the context menu.
Press the key combination CtrlI.
Execute the queued changes to actually install the package(s):
Click on Execute in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Execute from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlE.

sect2.title: Removing Packages
sect2.para: To remove one or more packages follow these steps:

listitem.para:
Select the package(s) that you wish to remove in the
.
Queue the selected package(s) for removal:
Click on Remove in the package control area.
Choose Package Remove from the menu.
Right click on the package and choose Remove from the context menu.
Press the key combination CtrlR.
Execute the queued changes to actually remove the package(s):
Click on Execute in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Execute from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlE.

note.para: Configuration files and user created data (e.g. a Webiste in /var/www) are not removed from the system by default. You can change this behavior in the .
Alternativly, choose PackagesPurge with Configuration from the menu to remove all files related to the package.

sect2.title: Upgrading Single Packages
sect2.para: To upgrade one or more packages follow these steps:

listitem.para: Query the package repositories for the latest version of the package(s):
Choose Actions Update from the menu.
Click on Update in the toolbar.

Select the package(s) that you wish to upgrade in the
.
Queue the selected packages for upgrade:
Click on Upgrade in the package control area.
Choose Package Upgrade from the menu.
Right click on the package and choose Upgrade from the context menu.
Press the key combination CtrlU.
Execute the queued changes to actually upgrade the package(s):
Click on Execute in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Execute from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlE.

tip.para: To upgrade all installed packages to the latest version, see .

sect2.title: Upgrading System
sect2.para: The global upgrade enables you to upgrade your system to the latest version without having to queue each package upgrade manually.

&app; provides two global upgrade methods:
Upgrade
The default upgrade method queues upgrades of installed packages only. If the later version of a package depends on not installed packages or conflicts with an allready installed package, the upgrade will not be queued.
Dist-Upgrade
Dist-Upgrade tries to resolve package conflicts intelligently. This includes installing additional required packages and prefering packages with higher priority.

note.para: Upgrades to later operating system major releases have to be done with the dist-upgrade method, e.g. from Red Hat 9 to Red Hat 9.1 or from Debian Woody to Debian Sarge.

sect2.para: To upgrade your system to the latest version follow these steps:

listitem.para: Query the package repositories for the latest version of the packages:
Choose Actions Update Package List from the menu.
Click on Update List in the toolbar.
Queue the package(s) for upgrade:
Click on Upgrade All Packages in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Upgrade All Packages from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlU.
Choose the upgrade method. Dist-upgrade is recommended.
Execute the queued changes to actually upgrade the package(s):
Click on Execute in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Execute from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlE.

tip.para: You can change the default upgrade method in the .

sect2.title: Downgrading Packages

warning.para: Downgrading packages is a broken feature, since apt and &app; can only handle conflicts and dependency resolution in upgrades. You may need this feature in some circumstances, but it is not recommended to use.

sect2.para: To downgrade a package you have to select a speficic version of the package:

listitem.para: Select the package that you wish to downgrade in the .
Open the Expert tab in the detail area.
Choose the version to be installed from the list.
Execute the queued changes to actually downgrade the package(s):
Click on Execute in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Execute from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlE.

sect1.title: Using Filters
sect1.para: Filters enable you to narrow down the list of shown packages in the main package list.

sect2.title: Applying Predefined Filters
sect2.para: &app; comes with a list of predifend filters.

row.entry: Displays only currently not installed packages.
Displays only packages with a later version available.
Displays only packages with broken dependencies.
Displays only packages queued to be modified.
Displays only new packages since the last repository update.
Displays only former installed packages that left data or configuration files on the system.
Displays only packages that can be configured through the debian package configuration system, so called debconf.
Displays only packages that are not (for longer) included in one of the specified repositories.

listitem.para: Choose ViewApply Filter FILTERNAME.
Choose the filter from the Show combobox in the main window.

sect2.title: Editing and Creating Filters
sect2.para: Filters can be created, deleted and modified in the filter editor. There are two to start the editor:

Click on Filters... in the main window
